TopicTitle: Copehnagen suborbitals is testing to use nitrogen instead of helium to presurice tanks

Articles.Content:
They are doing it because a big cost reduction, for the same 10.000 liters bottle, helium cost 1450 $ and nitrogen cost 22 $.

It looks like they will "only" use it in tests

https://copenhagensuborbitals.com/helium-versus-nitrogen/

I'm pretty sure this is standard procedure (for testing tanks), although typically for things a lot more expensive than helium.  I'd be a bit worried about using different gasses during actual engine tests.

Saw an error in the cost conversion. 2000 kr=0.144*2000=$288, this also match with the nitrogen cost. 

They will use it for static burn tests to, looks like main issue is that nitrogen dissolves in the lox over time,
Yes, also nitrogen might react with the lox, making NO2.
